title: HTTP Server Parity: Legacy Python Exact Match
description:
Purpose:
Achieve *exact* HTTP + MCP parity with legacy Python mcp_agent_mail server behavior. This epic owns every remaining HTTP-path gap and ensures parity is proven with unit tests, conformance fixtures, and detailed E2E scripts. No "best-of-both-worlds" deviations.

Scope (must be 1:1 with Python behavior):
- JWT auth: HS256 + JWKS, audience/issuer validation, role claim extraction
- RBAC behavior tied to roles and localhost bypass
- Redis-backed token-bucket rate limiting with Lua script parity
- Accurate client peer address detection for localhost bypass + rate limit identity
- Stateless Streamable HTTP MCP transport behavior (Accept/Content-Type normalization, base path mount, passthrough route, Authorization injection)
- SSR Mail UI under /mail/* with template + markdown/sanitization parity
- HTTP request logging + optional OTEL hooks parity (if enabled in config)
- CORS parity (origins/methods/headers/credentials)

Non-goals:
- No new endpoints or UX changes beyond legacy behavior
- No compatibility shims; fix Rust directly
- No tokio usage; only asupersync/fastmcp/sqlmodel/etc per repo rules

Cross-repo dependencies:
- asupersync bead `bd-32eba` (peer_addr on Http1Request) and its children. This is a hard blocker for localhost parity and rate-limit identity.

Definition of Done:
- All child tasks complete
- Conformance fixtures updated and passing for HTTP scenarios
- Dedicated unit tests pass for each subsystem
- E2E scripts pass with detailed logging (auth, rate limits, /mail UI)
- Manual spot-check parity passes (health endpoints, auth flows, rate limiting, /mail UI)

Notes for future maintainers:
- Always compare against legacy mcp_agent_mail/src/mcp_agent_mail/http.py
- Prefer explicit test vectors over "implicit" correctness
- Keep error payloads identical (status + JSON body)

title: JWT Auth Parity (HS256 + JWKS + role claim)
description:
Objective:
Implement JWT authentication exactly as in legacy Python (mcp_agent_mail/http.py). This includes HS256 HMAC and JWKS verification paths, audience/issuer validation, role extraction, and error semantics. Must be 1:1 on outputs and failure modes.

Legacy Reference Behavior (must match):
- If JWT enabled and Authorization missing or not Bearer: 401 {"detail":"Unauthorized"}
- Decode token using:
  - If JWKS URL set: fetch JWKS, select key by header.kid, verify
  - Else if secret set: verify with HMAC secret
  - Algorithms from HTTP_JWT_ALGORITHMS (default HS256)
- Validate audience/issuer if configured; otherwise ignore
- On any failure: 401 {"detail":"Unauthorized"}
- Extract roles from claim HTTP_JWT_ROLE_CLAIM (default "role")
  - String -> singleton set
  - List/tuple -> set of strings
  - Else -> empty
- If roles empty, use HTTP_RBAC_DEFAULT_ROLE
- Store claims for rate limit identity (sub) and any downstream uses

Implementation Considerations:
- JWKS fetch must be async-safe via asupersync HTTP client (no tokio)
- Cache JWKS by URL with TTL to avoid per-request latency
- Must not change external response schema or status codes
- Log auth failures at debug/trace (no extra HTTP output)

Tests (must include detailed logging):
Unit tests:
- Missing Authorization header -> 401
- Non-Bearer Authorization -> 401
- HS256 valid/invalid signatures
- JWKS valid/invalid (kid missing, bad signature)
- Audience/issuer mismatch -> 401
- Role claim variants (string, list, missing)
Integration tests:
- Start server with HTTP_JWT_* env vars; make requests with valid/invalid JWT
- Verify RBAC path uses roles correctly
E2E script (with logs):
- Script to launch server, run curl/httpx cases, capture stdout/stderr to logs
- Log each case with expected vs actual HTTP status + JSON body

Dependencies:
- br-1bm.3 (client peer address) for localhost bypass parity

Acceptance Criteria:
- JWT behavior matches legacy for all test vectors
- Role extraction matches Python behavior
- E2E logs show pass/fail for each case; script exits non-zero on mismatch

description: Extract exact JWT behavior from legacy http.py/authlib usage and document concrete test vectors. Include: header parsing, JWKS key selection (kid), allowed algorithms, audience/issuer validation rules, exp/nbf handling, and role claim parsing rules. Produce a matrix of inputs -> expected HTTP status/body. This task defines the ground-truth spec used by all other JWT tasks.

title: JWT Parity: JWKS fetch + cache

title: JWT Parity: HS256 HMAC validation
description: Implement HS256 validation path using shared secret when JWKS URL is not set. Must respect HTTP_JWT_ALGORITHMS; reject if algorithm not allowed or signature invalid. Match Python failure semantics (401 Unauthorized).

title: JWT Parity: claim validation + RBAC role extraction
description: Implement aud/iss/exp/nbf validation and role extraction exactly as legacy. Role claim name = HTTP_JWT_ROLE_CLAIM, defaults when empty. Store claims in request context for rate-limit identity (sub).

Integration tests spin up server with env config and hit HTTP endpoints. E2E script runs scripted curl/httpx cases, logs expected vs actual status/body, and exits non-zero on mismatch. Keep logs in tests/artifacts/jwt/ with timestamps.

title: Redis Rate Limiting Parity (token bucket)
description:
Objective:
Implement Redis-backed token-bucket rate limiting exactly as legacy Python when HTTP_RATE_LIMIT_BACKEND=redis and HTTP_RATE_LIMIT_ENABLED=true. Must match key format, Lua script semantics, TTL, and fallback behavior.

Legacy Reference Behavior:
- Enabled when settings.http.rate_limit_enabled.
- Key format: "rl:{kind}:{endpoint}:{identity}".
- Identity uses request.client.host unless JWT claims sub present (then use "sub:{sub}").
- Lua token bucket (HMGET/HMSET, EXPIRE with ceil(burst/max(rate,0.001))).
- Burst defaults to max(1, rpm) when configured burst is 0.
- On Redis failure, fallback to in-memory bucket.

Implementation Considerations:
- Use asupersync Redis client (no tokio, no external redis crate).
- Ensure monotonic time source for token math.
- Memory buckets cleanup identical to Python (evict after 1h idle).
- Keep HTTP response payloads identical (429 + {"detail":"Rate limit exceeded"}).

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
Unit tests:
- Key format, identity derivation, burst default behavior, TTL calculation.
- Deterministic token bucket math with simulated time.
Integration tests:
- Redis-backed allow/deny with known sequences (require Redis test fixture).
- Redis failure -> memory fallback, verify logs.
E2E script:
- Start server with rate limiting on, send burst of requests, verify 429 thresholds.
- Log each request timestamp, expected allow/deny, and actual response.

Dependencies:
- br-1bm.3 (peer address) for correct identity
- br-1bm.1 (JWT parity) for sub-based identity

Acceptance Criteria:
- Redis backend matches Python decisions for identical sequences.
- Fallback to memory is correct and logged.
- E2E script passes with explicit allow/deny log lines.

title: Rate Limit Parity: extract legacy Lua + vectors

title: Rate Limit Parity: Redis Lua implementation
description: Implement the Redis Lua token bucket using asupersync Redis client. Must match HMGET/HMSET, tokens/ts math, and EXPIRE logic exactly. Ensure key prefix rl: and correct namespace. Log Redis errors and fall back cleanly.

title: Rate Limit Parity: identity derivation (host/sub)
description: Implement identity selection logic: prefer JWT sub when available, else client host (peer address). Ensure forwarded headers do not override peer address. Matches legacy behavior. Requires peer_addr + JWT tasks.

title: Rate Limit Parity: memory fallback + cleanup
description: Implement in-memory token bucket fallback identical to Python (monotonic time, burst/rate math, cleanup of buckets idle >1h). Ensure fallback triggers on Redis errors without changing HTTP output.

title: Rate Limit Parity: unit + integration + E2E tests
description: Comprehensive tests with detailed logging. Unit tests for key format, burst defaults, TTL calculation, and deterministic token math. Integration tests with Redis fixture (allow/deny sequences). E2E script runs request bursts, logs expected vs actual allow/deny, writes artifacts to tests/artifacts/rate_limit/.

title: Client Peer Address + Localhost Bypass Parity
description:
Objective:
Accurately detect client host/peer address for localhost bypass, RBAC, and rate limiting identity. Must match legacy Python logic, including IPv4-mapped IPv6 handling and forwarded header safeguards.

Legacy Reference Behavior:
- Determine client_host from request.client.host
- If forwarded headers present (x-forwarded-for/proto/host or forwarded), treat as non-local
- Localhost if client_host in {"127.0.0.1","::1","localhost"} or IPv4-mapped ::ffff:127.0.0.1
- When localhost allowed and bearer token set, auto-inject Authorization in base path passthrough

Implementation Plan:
1. Integrate peer_addr from asupersync Http1Request (external dependency bd-32eba).
2. Add helper to normalize peer_addr to client_host string (supports IPv4-mapped IPv6).
3. Update allow_local_unauthenticated checks to use peer address + forwarded headers.
4. Use client_host for rate-limit identity when JWT sub absent.

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
Unit tests:
- IPv4 localhost
- IPv6 localhost
- IPv4-mapped IPv6 localhost
- Forwarded headers disable localhost bypass
Integration tests:
- Simulate Http1Request with peer_addr variations
E2E script:
- Start server with allow_localhost_unauthenticated and bearer token
- Requests from localhost should succeed without Authorization; forwarded headers should fail

External Dependency:
- asupersync bead `bd-32eba` and children must land first.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Localhost bypass behavior matches legacy Python for all cases
- Rate-limit identity uses peer address when JWT sub is missing
- E2E logs show explicit pass/fail for each client host case

title: Peer Addr Parity: integrate asupersync Http1Request.peer_addr
description: Wire peer_addr from asupersync Http1Request into server logic. This is blocked on external asupersync bead bd-32eba. Once available, update server request handling to read peer_addr and expose helper to derive client_host string.

E2E script starts server, sends requests with/without Authorization, logs expected vs actual outcomes; include forwarded header cases. Store logs under tests/artifacts/peer_addr/.

title: Stateless Streamable HTTP MCP Parity
description:
Objective:
Reproduce legacy Python stateless Streamable HTTP behavior for MCP requests, including header normalization, base path mount semantics, passthrough route, and localhost Authorization injection. Must be wire-compatible for existing MCP clients.

Legacy Reference Behavior:
- Per-request StreamableHTTPServerTransport, stateless=True
- Accept header forced to "application/json, text/event-stream"
- Content-Type added for POST if missing
- Base path mounted at both /base and /base/ (no redirect)
- Direct POST handler at base path that forwards to mounted app
- If localhost + allow_localhost_unauthenticated + bearer token set, inject Authorization if missing
- Responses passed through without extra wrapping

Implementation Considerations:
- Use fastmcp_rust transport primitives (no tokio)
- Preserve request/response JSON-RPC payloads exactly
- Avoid breaking SSE/streaming semantics

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
Unit tests:
- Header normalization (Accept, Content-Type)
- Base path normalization logic
Integration tests:
- Requests to /api and /api/ both succeed
- Passthrough handler returns same body/status as mounted handler
E2E script:
- Start server and run curl/httpx cases with missing headers
- Include localhost auth injection case
- Log expected vs actual response code/body

Dependencies:
- br-1bm.3 (peer address) for localhost detection

Acceptance Criteria:
- Wire behavior matches legacy Python for all HTTP edge cases
- E2E script passes with explicit logs

title: Streamable HTTP Parity: extract legacy behaviors + fixtures

description: Implement base path handling: mount at /base and /base/ and add direct POST handler at /base (no redirect) that forwards into mounted app. Ensure path normalization matches legacy (base_no_slash + base_with_slash).

title: Streamable HTTP Parity: localhost auth injection
description: If allow_localhost_unauthenticated and peer_addr is localhost and Authorization missing, inject Bearer token for base path passthrough (only when bearer token configured). Must respect forwarded headers (no bypass).

title: Streamable HTTP Parity: stateless transport pass-through

title: Streamable HTTP Parity: unit + integration + E2E tests
description: Comprehensive tests with detailed logging. Unit tests for header normalization + base path logic. Integration tests for /api and /api/ parity and passthrough correctness. E2E script covers missing headers, localhost auth injection, and streaming response sanity. Log expected vs actual results and store artifacts under tests/artifacts/http_streamable/.

title: Mail SSR UI Parity (/mail/*)
description:
Objective:
Implement the legacy Python SSR Mail UI endpoints under /mail/* with identical behavior and output expectations. This includes templates, markdown rendering, sanitization, and static assets. Must be safe and stable for human overseer usage.

Legacy Reference Behavior:
- /mail and /mail/* routes render HTML using Jinja templates
- Markdown rendering via markdown2; sanitization via bleach + optional CSS sanitizer
- Supports inbox list, thread view, compose, human overseer actions
- Static assets served from legacy web/ and templates/ directories

Implementation Considerations:
- Must preserve HTML structure and CSS class names to keep UI stable
- Sanitization allowlist must match or be stricter without breaking expected markup
- Cache headers should match legacy defaults for static assets

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
Unit tests:
- Markdown rendering + sanitization with malicious inputs
- Template rendering for key pages
Integration tests:
- Render HTML for a known dataset and snapshot output
E2E script:
- Start server, fetch /mail pages, verify status + key DOM markers
- Log expected vs actual results and store artifacts under tests/artifacts/mail_ui/

Acceptance Criteria:
- /mail and /mail/* routes function as legacy
- Sanitization prevents XSS while preserving expected formatting
- E2E logs show explicit pass/fail for each page

description: Enumerate all /mail routes, templates, and static assets in legacy code. Produce a route map, template list, and asset manifest. This is the authoritative UI spec for the Rust port.

description: Implement markdown rendering and HTML sanitization to match legacy (markdown2 + bleach + optional CSS sanitizer). Define allowlist and ensure unsafe HTML is stripped. Preserve expected formatting.

description: Port Jinja templates (or equivalent) and implement data binding for inbox list, thread view, compose, and human overseer actions. Preserve structure and class names to maintain UI parity.

description: Serve static CSS/JS/assets under /mail with correct content-type and caching headers. Mirror legacy asset paths and filenames. Ensure assets are bundled in crate resources if needed.

description: Comprehensive tests with detailed logging. Unit tests for sanitization and markdown rendering. Integration tests for template rendering snapshots. E2E script fetches /mail pages, validates DOM markers and status codes, logs expected vs actual results, stores artifacts under tests/artifacts/mail_ui/.

title: HTTP Request Logging + OTEL Parity
description:
Objective:
Implement HTTP request logging and optional OTEL hooks exactly as legacy Python when enabled by config (HTTP_REQUEST_LOG_ENABLED, HTTP_OTEL_ENABLED). Logging must be human-readable and not alter HTTP responses.

Legacy Reference Behavior:
- When request logging enabled, log method/path/status/latency/client in rich panel (fallback to plain text if rich unavailable).
- Logging must not interfere with response or error handling.
- OTEL settings exist; if enabled, hooks should be prepared (even if no exporter available) without crashing.

Implementation Considerations:
- Use frankentui or existing logging facilities for rich output.
- Ensure log output is disabled when not configured (no noise).
- Do not change stdout/stderr behavior expected by MCP clients.

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
- Unit tests for logger formatting and structured fields.
- Integration tests verifying logs emitted only when enabled.
- E2E script: run server with logging enabled, issue requests, assert log lines/fields present.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Logging matches legacy format and content.
- OTEL settings do not crash server if misconfigured.
- E2E logs captured and verified.

title: HTTP Logging Parity: extract legacy behavior
description: Extract exact logging behavior from legacy (rich panel format, fields, fallback text). Define expected log lines/fields and conditions when logging is enabled.

description: Implement request logging middleware that matches legacy output (method/path/status/latency/client). Use frankentui for rich output where appropriate, fallback to plain text. Must be silent when disabled.

title: HTTP Logging Parity: OTEL hooks
description: Wire optional OTEL hooks per config (HTTP_OTEL_ENABLED, OTEL_SERVICE_NAME, OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT). Must not crash if endpoint unavailable; logs should indicate disabled/misconfigured state without changing HTTP output.

title: HTTP Logging Parity: unit + integration + E2E tests

E2E script launches server with logging on, issues requests, captures logs to artifacts/tests/http_logging/ and asserts expected fields.

title: CORS Parity Validation
description:
Objective:
Validate and complete CORS behavior parity with legacy Python: origins, allow_methods, allow_headers, allow_credentials, and OPTIONS responses. Ensure behavior matches when lists are empty or "*".

Legacy Reference Behavior:
- If CORS enabled, allow_origins defaults to ["*"] when empty
- allow_methods default ["*"]
- allow_headers default ["*"]
- Credentials flag respected

Implementation Plan:
- Ensure CORS config parsing matches legacy defaults (already added fields)
- Verify OPTIONS responses include appropriate headers
- Ensure origin matching allows all when list is empty

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
- Unit tests for allowlist matching and default behavior
- Integration tests for OPTIONS + GET/POST with Origin set
- E2E script: send CORS preflight, log headers and assert expected values

Acceptance Criteria:
- CORS headers match legacy defaults and behavior
- E2E logs capture header values and pass/fail

title: Bearer Auth Parity
description:
Objective:
Ensure Bearer token auth middleware behavior matches legacy Python, including localhost bypass logic and forwarded-header safeguards.

Legacy Reference Behavior:
- If bearer token configured, require Authorization: Bearer <token>
- If allow_localhost_unauthenticated and client is localhost (no forwarded headers), bypass Authorization
- OPTIONS and /health/* always allowed
- Constant-time comparison for token equality

Implementation Plan:
- Verify Rust middleware path covers OPTIONS + /health/* bypass
- Enforce constant-time token compare
- Use peer_addr + forwarded headers for localhost detection (br-1bm.3)

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
- Unit tests for token comparison + bypass conditions
- Integration tests for /health endpoints, OPTIONS, and standard POSTs
- E2E script: run server with bearer token; test localhost bypass and forwarded header failure; log expected vs actual

Acceptance Criteria:
- Responses and bypass behavior match legacy exactly
- E2E logs demonstrate correct allow/deny

title: Health + Well-Known Endpoints Parity Tests
description:
Objective:
Verify health and well-known endpoints match legacy behavior and remain stable. Ensure status codes and JSON payloads are identical.

Endpoints:
- GET /health/liveness -> {"status":"alive"}
- GET /health/readiness -> {"status":"ready"} or 503 {"detail":"..."}
- GET /.well-known/oauth-authorization-server -> {"mcp_oauth": false}
- GET /.well-known/oauth-authorization-server/mcp -> {"mcp_oauth": false}

Tests and E2E (with detailed logging):
- Unit tests for readiness error formatting
- Integration tests for each endpoint and method mismatch (405)
- E2E script: hit each endpoint, log status/body, fail on mismatch

Acceptance Criteria:
- JSON payloads and status codes identical to legacy
- E2E logs show pass/fail for each endpoint

title: Conformance: assert git archive artifacts (messages/inbox/outbox/reservations/attachments) match legacy
description:
Extend conformance beyond JSON tool outputs to verify archive side effects.

Artifacts to assert after running a fixture script:
- messages/YYYY/MM/*.md canonical exists; parses frontmatter JSON; body matches expected.
- agents/<Agent>/inbox + outbox copies exist and match canonical.
- file_reservations/*.json artifacts exist for created reservations.
- attachments manifests + WebP/originals as expected.

Strategy:
- Fixture generator should record expected relative paths and key frontmatter fields, not absolute machine paths.
- Use hashing for large binaries; compare sha256.
- Allow nondeterministic timestamps but assert ordering and presence.

Dependencies:
- Requires storage layer implementation.

title: Storage: Git archive write/read pipeline + attachments
description:
Implement the git-backed mailbox archive described in EXISTING_MCP_AGENT_MAIL_STRUCTURE.md.

This is the core missing subsystem: legacy Python writes messages + file reservations + attachments into a per-project git repo and uses it as an auditable artifact store.

Scope (must match legacy behavior):
- Archive root creation + .gitattributes
- Per-project advisory locks (.archive.lock + owner metadata)
- Commit batching queue (max 10, max wait 50ms)
- Message write pipeline:
  - canonical messages/YYYY/MM/*.md
  - agents/<Agent>/inbox + outbox copies
  - thread digest files (messages/threads/<thread_id>.md) if present in legacy
  - git commit message format
- File reservation artifacts (file_reservations/<sha1(pattern)>.json + id-<id>.json)
- Attachment pipeline:
  - compute content hashes
  - convert images to WebP when enabled
  - inline small attachments (< 64KiB) into markdown
  - keep originals when configured
  - write manifests + audit logs
- Read helpers for resources that include commit metadata.

Constraints:
- Prefer git2 library (already in workspace deps); avoid shelling out when possible.
- Prefer asupersync for IO/concurrency.

Acceptance:
- New conformance layer can assert archive artifacts exactly match legacy (file layout + frontmatter JSON + markdown body).
- Benchmarks can measure write throughput and commit batching.

title: Archive: initialize archive root + per-project git repos + .gitattributes
description:
Implement archive initialization in mcp-agent-mail-storage.

Requirements:
- Determine archive root from Config.storage_root (default ~/.mcp_agent_mail_git_mailbox_repo).
- Ensure root exists.
- For each project slug, ensure a git repo exists at <root>/<slug>/.
- Ensure expected top-level dirs exist: agents/, messages/, attachments/, file_reservations/.
- Write .gitattributes (at least: enforce LF for *.md and binary for images).
- Ensure git author identity set from config (name/email) for commits.

Implementation:
- Use git2 to init and commit initial scaffolding if repo newly created.

Acceptance:
- Idempotent: calling multiple times does not change repo.
- Unit test with temp dir.

title: Archive: per-project advisory locks + commit batching queue
description:
Implement concurrency control for archive writes.

Spec:
- Per-project advisory lock file: <project>/.archive.lock (+ optional owner metadata JSON).
- Commit queue batching: max 10 commits or max wait 50ms.
- Stale lock cleanup on startup.

Implementation notes:
- Use filesystem lock (cross-platform) + busy-timeout retry. Prefer asupersync primitives if available.
- Keep API simple for callers: `with_project_lock(project_slug, || ...)`.
- Batching should preserve ordering for operations within a single process.

Acceptance:
- Unit tests simulate concurrent lock acquisition.
- Bench: lock acquisition overhead is low.

title: Archive: message write pipeline (canonical + inbox/outbox + commit) + frontmatter format
description:
Implement message archival writes that mirror legacy Python.

Spec (EXISTING_MCP_AGENT_MAIL_STRUCTURE.md):
- Canonical: messages/YYYY/MM/<timestamp>__<subject_slug>__<id>.md
- Outbox: agents/<sender>/outbox/YYYY/MM/... (same rel path)
- Inboxes: agents/<recipient>/inbox/YYYY/MM/...
- Frontmatter: JSON preceded by ---json header line, then Markdown body.
- Git commit summary: "message <id> from <sender> to <recipients>".

Inputs:
- Message record + recipients + markdown body + attachments metadata.

Outputs:
- Files written atomically.
- Git commit performed (or batched) and commit info stored/returned where needed.

Acceptance:
- Deterministic path + slug generation.
- Conformance can assert files exist and parse.

title: Archive: file reservation artifacts (sha1(pattern).json + id-<id>.json)
description:

- file_reservations/<sha1(path_pattern)>.json

Requirements:
- JSON includes {id, agent, path_pattern, exclusive, reason, created_ts, expires_ts, released_ts} at minimum.
- Writes are atomic.
- Archive writes happen on reservation create/update/release and are committed (or batched).

Acceptance:
- Resource `resource://file_reservations/{slug}` can be backed by archive artifacts (optional) and/or DB.
- Conformance can assert artifact existence.

title: Archive: attachment pipeline (hashing, WebP conversion, manifests, inline small)

- attachments/_manifests/<sha1>.json
- attachments/_audit/<sha1>.log

Behavior:
- Convert images to WebP when enabled; disable when stderr not tty? (mirror legacy policy).
- Inline attachments <= 64KiB into markdown; store larger attachments as files and reference via manifest.
- Optionally keep originals.
- Ensure deterministic hashing + stable paths.

Acceptance:
- Conformance can assert archive artifacts and message frontmatter attachment refs.

title: Archive: read helpers + commit metadata (mailbox-with-commits/outbox/inbox views)

Implement archive reads used by resources that include commit context.

title: Reservations: implement force_release_file_reservation (inactivity heuristics + optional notify)
description:
Implement force-release stale file reservations (MCP tool).

Spec:
- Validates reservation appears abandoned:
  - agent inactive beyond threshold
  - no recent mail activity
  - no recent filesystem/git activity (archive)
- When released, optionally notify previous holder with note.

Implementation plan:
- Define what signals we can reliably measure in Rust:
  - agent.last_active_ts in DB
  - message activity timestamps
  - archive activity timestamps (last commit touching agent/mail artifacts)
- Implement heuristics with conservative defaults and clear audit trail.
- Write release to DB + archive artifacts.
- If notify_previous=true: send_message to previous holder (threaded) explaining forced release.

Acceptance:
- Conformance fixture covers both allow/deny paths.
- Safety: only force-release when heuristics strongly indicate abandonment.

title: Guard: pre-commit/pre-push enforcement + install/uninstall tooling
description:
Implement the Agent Mail guard system (pre-commit / pre-push hooks) that prevents edits when exclusive file reservations conflict.

Spec source:
- EXISTING_MCP_AGENT_MAIL_STRUCTURE.md section "Guard Behavior (Pre-Commit / Pre-Push)"

Scope:
- `mcp-agent-mail-guard` crate:
  - install_guard(project, repo): resolves hooks dir (core.hooksPath or default), writes chain-runner hooks, writes plugin scripts under hooks.d/<hook>.
  - uninstall_guard(repo): removes our plugins; removes chain-runner only if safe (no other plugins) and restores .orig if applicable.
  - guard_status(repo): reports resolved hooks path + presence of pre-commit/pre-push + mode.
  - guard_check(repo, paths, advisory): checks active file reservations and returns conflicts (pattern, holder, expires_ts).
- MCP tools:
  - install_precommit_guard(project_key, code_repo_path)
  - uninstall_precommit_guard(code_repo_path)
  - (later) force_release_file_reservation uses similar heuristics.
- CLI wiring:
  - `am guard install|uninstall|status|check` should call guard crate.

Implementation notes:
- Use git2 to discover repo + read config.
- Path matching: prefer pathspec (gitignore syntax) with fnmatch symmetric fallback.
- Must respect env vars: AGENT_MAIL_GUARD_MODE, AGENT_MAIL_BYPASS, AGENT_NAME.

Acceptance:
- Conformance fixtures cover install/uninstall outputs.
- Unit tests cover path matching + rename handling + worktree hooks resolution.

title: Guard: resolve repo + hooks dir (core.hooksPath, worktrees) via git2
description:
Implement robust hooks directory resolution.

Requirements:
- Input: repo working tree path (code_repo_path).
- Discover git repo (supports worktrees).
- Determine hooks dir:
  - If core.hooksPath is set: resolve relative to repo root per git semantics.
  - Else: use default hooks dir for the repository common dir.
- Return resolved hooks_dir as a real filesystem path.

Must handle:
- .git is a file containing gitdir: ...
- worktrees where hooks live in common dir
- bare repo (if encountered) -> treat as invalid for hook install

Deliverable:
- `mcp_agent_mail_guard::resolve_hooks_dir(repo: &Path) -> GuardResult<PathBuf>` (or equivalent internal helper) with unit tests.
close_reason: Implemented resolve_hooks_dir via git2 + commondir parsing; added unit tests incl. worktree case.

title: Guard: install/uninstall chain-runner hooks + agent-mail plugin scripts
description:
Implement install/uninstall mechanics (pre-commit and optionally pre-push).

Install behavior (match legacy):
- Ensure hooks.d/<hook>/ directory exists.
- Write/overwrite top-level hook script (chain-runner) that executes hooks.d/<hook>/* in lexical order.
- Preserve existing non-chain hook as <hook>.orig.
- Install our plugin under hooks.d/<hook>/50-agent-mail (or equivalent) that executes the actual guard check.
- Create Windows shims (.cmd/.ps1) if needed to invoke the chain-runner.

Uninstall behavior:
- Remove our plugins (hooks.d/<hook>/50-agent-mail.*).
- Only remove chain-runner if it is ours AND there are no other plugins remaining AND no .orig restoration is needed.
- If .orig exists and chain-runner is removed, restore it.

Deliverables:
- `install_guard(project_key, repo)` writes files and chmods +x on unix.
- `uninstall_guard(repo)` removes/restores safely.
- Unit tests use temp git repos.
close_reason: Implemented install_guard/uninstall_guard: resolves hooks dir, installs python chain-runner + Windows shims, installs plugin stub, preserves/restores existing hook via .orig; added unit test for preserve/restore.

title: Guard: implement conflict detection (reservations + path matching + rename handling)
description:
Implement the actual guard decision logic.

Inputs:
- repo path
- list of paths to check (from staged diff for pre-commit, from commit range for pre-push)
- AGENT_NAME env var identifies current agent
- mode: block vs warn (AGENT_MAIL_GUARD_MODE)
- bypass env: AGENT_MAIL_BYPASS=1

Logic:
- If guard disabled (WORKTREES_ENABLED or GIT_IDENTITY_ENABLED false): allow.
- Load active file reservations for the project identity associated with repo (project_identity_mode logic).
- If any exclusive reservation matches any path (symmetric matching) and reservation holder != AGENT_NAME and unexpired: conflict.
- For renames: treat both old and new paths as touched.

Deliverables:
- Pure function that returns conflicts (pattern, holder, expires_ts) for a given path list.
- Helper to obtain staged paths from git: use `git diff --cached --name-only -z --diff-filter=ACMRDTU` and rename pairs from `--name-status -M -z`.
- Helper to obtain pre-push paths from stdin refs (`git rev-list`) with fallback to `git diff --name-status -M -z <remote>..<local>`.

Tests:
- Synthetic reservations + path lists.
- Temp repo with staged rename.

- Prefer asupersync for IO.

Acceptance:

- Bundle is deterministic for same inputs (stable ordering + hashing).
- Benchmarks for export path (time + output size).
